meanings.def: to make pictures, or a picture of something, with a pencil, pen or chalk (but not paint)
examples: You draw beautifully.
draw something to draw a picture/map/diagram
She drew a house.
a crudely drawn child's face
draw something with something He drew a circle in the sand with a stick.

meanings.def: to describe something in words in a way that produces an image in somebody's mind
examples: The report drew a grim picture of inefficiency and corruption.
She writes lively stories with sharply drawn characters.

meanings.def: to have a particular idea after you have studied something or thought about it
examples: draw something Is it possible to draw inferences about the environment during the Bronze Age?
draw something from something What conclusions did you draw from the report?
We can draw some lessons for the future from this accident.

meanings.def: to express a comparison or a contrast; to define the limits of something
examples: to draw a comparison/a parallel/an analogy/a distinction between two events
He attempted to draw a contrast between himself and the prime minister.
The site's boundaries were tightly drawn by the Department of the Environment.

meanings.def: to produce a reaction or response
examples: draw something The plan has drawn a lot of criticism.
draw something from somebody The announcement drew loud applause from the audience.
The proposal has drawn interest from local businessmen.
The reforms drew widespread support from voters.

meanings.def: to direct or attract somebody's attention to something
examples: Our aim is to draw attention to the plight of these children.
The exhibition drew great critical attention.
My eyes were drawn to the man in the corner.
Her gaze was drawn irresistibly to the scene outside.

meanings.def: to attract or interest somebody
examples: draw somebody The movie is drawing large audiences.
The events continue to draw huge crowds.
The course draws students from all over the country.
draw somebody to something Her screams drew passers-by to the scene.
We asked the surfing champion what first drew him to the sport.
Animals are instinctively drawn to those who like them.
He was increasingly drawn to the idea of making short films.

meanings.def: to move in the direction mentioned
examples: The train drew into the station.
The train drew in.
The figures in the distance seemed to be drawing closer.
Their car drew alongside ours.
(figurative) Her retirement is drawing near.
(figurative) The meeting was drawing to a close.
As he drew near, I could see that he was limping.
as the boat drew towards the shore
He approached her but she drew away.

meanings.def: to move something/somebody by pulling it or them gently
examples: He drew the cork out of the bottle.
I drew my chair up closer to the fire.
She drew me onto the balcony.
I tried to draw him aside (= for example where I could talk to him privately).
She sat with her legs drawn up on the sofa.
(figurative) The project enables students to draw together their knowledge, skills and experience.
Pull the chair nearer the table.
They use oxen to pull their carts.
The sack is too heavy to lift—you’ll have to drag it.
I drew my chair closer to the fire.
a horse-drawn carriage
Fishermen were hauling in their nets.
Our car was towed away by the police.
She tried to escape but he tugged her back.

meanings.def: to pull a vehicle such as a carriage
examples: be drawn by something The Queen's coach was drawn by six horses.
a horse-drawn carriage

meanings.def: to open or close curtains, etc.
examples: The blinds were drawn.
It was getting dark so I switched on the light and drew the curtains.
She drew back the curtains and let the sunlight in.

meanings.def: to take out a weapon, such as a gun or a sword, in order to attack somebody
examples: She drew a revolver on me.
He came towards them with his sword drawn.

meanings.def: to make somebody say more about something
examples: be drawn (about/on something) Spielberg refused to be drawn on his next movie.

meanings.def: to decide something by picking cards, tickets or numbers by chance
examples: draw for something We drew for partners.
draw something He drew the winning ticket.
draw something (from something) Names were drawn from a hat for the last few places.
be drawn against somebody/something Italy has been drawn against Spain in the first round.
draw somebody/something to do something Italy has been drawn to play Spain.

meanings.def: to finish a game without either team winning
examples: England and France drew.
England and France drew 3–3.
draw with/against somebody England drew with/against France.
draw something England drew their game against France.

meanings.def: to take money or payments from a bank account or post office
examples: draw something out (of something) I drew out £200.
Can I draw $80 out of my account?
draw something (from something) She went to the post office to draw her pension.
draw something on something The cheque was drawn on his personal account.

meanings.def: to take or pull liquid or gas from somewhere
examples: to draw water from a well
The device draws gas along the pipe.
The ducts draw out stale air.
The company has been drawing gas and oil out of the rich ground for 62 years.

meanings.def: to breathe in smoke or air
examples: draw at/on something He drew thoughtfully on his pipe.
draw something in She breathed deeply, drawing in the fresh mountain air.

meanings.def: if two people are at daggers drawn, they are very angry with each other
used to say that people or groups have shown which side they intend to support in an argument or contest that is going to begin
to aim carefully at somebody/something before shooting a gun
examples: One of the police officers drew a bead on the gunman and fired.

meanings.def: to get no response or result
examples: So far, the police investigation has drawn a blank.

meanings.def: to make somebody bleed
to stop doing something and rest
examples: She talks all the time and hardly stops to draw breath.
He spoke solidly for twenty minutes, barely pausing to draw breath.

meanings.def: to live; to be alive
examples: He was as kind a man as ever drew breath.

meanings.def: to make somebody direct their anger, criticism, etc. at you, so that others do not have to face it
to start being more careful in your behaviour, especially by spending less money than before
examples: Small businesses have had to pull their horns in during the recession.

meanings.def: to refuse to do something; to set a limit
examples: I don't mind helping, but I draw the line at doing everything myself.
We would have liked to invite all our relatives, but you have to draw the line somewhere.

meanings.def: to make a difference between two closely related ideas
examples: Where do you draw the line between genius and madness?

meanings.def: to say that something is finished and not worth discussing any more

to use a method of choosing somebody/something that involves putting a number folded pieces of paper in a bag, one of them with a mark on it. People then take it in turns to take a piece of paper from the bag and the one who takes the paper with the mark on it is chosen.
examples: They drew lots for the right to go first.

meanings.def: to be the person in a group who is chosen or forced to perform an unpleasant duty or task
examples: I drew the short straw and had to clean the toilets.

meanings.def: to use a method of choosing somebody to do or have something in which each person takes a piece of paper, etc. from a container and the one whose paper has a special mark is chosen
examples: We drew straws for who went first.

meanings.def: to stand straight and tall in order to show that you are determined, powerful or important
examples: He drew himself up to his full height and glared at us.

meanings.def: (to establish) a clear limit to what you will do or accept
examples: It’s time to draw a line in the sand and stop allowing workplace bullying to continue.

meanings.def: to speak to somebody in private, especially in order to warn or tell them about something

idioms.def: if two people are at daggers drawn, they are very angry with each other
used to say that people or groups have shown which side they intend to support in an argument or contest that is going to begin
to aim carefully at somebody/something before shooting a gun
examples: One of the police officers drew a bead on the gunman and fired.

idioms.def: to get no response or result
examples: So far, the police investigation has drawn a blank.

idioms.def: to stop doing something and rest
examples: She talks all the time and hardly stops to draw breath.
He spoke solidly for twenty minutes, barely pausing to draw breath.
He was as kind a man as ever drew breath.

idioms.def: to make somebody direct their anger, criticism, etc. at you, so that others do not have to face it
to start being more careful in your behaviour, especially by spending less money than before
examples: Small businesses have had to pull their horns in during the recession.

idioms.idiom: draw the line (at something/at doing something)
idioms.def: to refuse to do something; to set a limit
examples: I don't mind helping, but I draw the line at doing everything myself.
We would have liked to invite all our relatives, but you have to draw the line somewhere.

idioms.idiom: draw the line (between something and something)
idioms.def: to make a difference between two closely related ideas
examples: Where do you draw the line between genius and madness?

idioms.def: to say that something is finished and not worth discussing any more

to use a method of choosing somebody/something that involves putting a number folded pieces of paper in a bag, one of them with a mark on it. People then take it in turns to take a piece of paper from the bag and the one who takes the paper with the mark on it is chosen.
examples: They drew lots for the right to go first.

idioms.def: to be the person in a group who is chosen or forced to perform an unpleasant duty or task
examples: I drew the short straw and had to clean the toilets.

idioms.def: to use a method of choosing somebody to do or have something in which each person takes a piece of paper, etc. from a container and the one whose paper has a special mark is chosen
examples: We drew straws for who went first.

idioms.idiom: draw yourself up/rise to your full height
idioms.def: to stand straight and tall in order to show that you are determined, powerful or important
examples: He drew himself up to his full height and glared at us.

idioms.def: (to establish) a clear limit to what you will do or accept
examples: It’s time to draw a line in the sand and stop allowing workplace bullying to continue.

idioms.def: to speak to somebody in private, especially in order to warn or tell them about something

meanings.def: the act of choosing something, for example the winner of a prize or the teams who play each other in a competition, usually by taking pieces of paper, etc. out of a container without being able to see what is written on them
examples: the draw for the second round of the Champions League
The draw for the raffle takes place on Saturday.
I’m now going to call on the President to make the draw.

meanings.def: a competition in which the winners are chosen in a draw
examples: a prize draw

meanings.def: a game in which both teams or players finish with the same number of points
examples: The match ended in a two-all draw.
He managed to hold Smith to a draw (= to stop him from winning when he seemed likely to do so).
They could only manage a goalless draw at Upton Park.

meanings.def: a sports match for which the teams or players are chosen in a draw
examples: Liverpool have an away draw against Manchester United.

meanings.def: a set of matches for which the teams or players are chosen in a draw
examples: There are only two seeded players left in the top half of the draw.

meanings.def: a person, a thing or an event that attracts a lot of people
examples: She is currently one of the biggest draws on the Irish music scene.

meanings.def: an act of breathing in the smoke from a cigarette
examples: She took one last draw from the cigarette.

meanings.def: to be quick to understand or react in a new situation
examples: You can't fool him—he's always quick on the draw.

meanings.def: to be quick at pulling out a gun in order to shoot it
the fact that chance decides something, in a way that you cannot control
examples: To a large extent the life you have depends on who your parents were; it’s just the luck of the biological draw.

idioms.def: to be quick to understand or react in a new situation
examples: You can't fool him—he's always quick on the draw.

idioms.def: the fact that chance decides something, in a way that you cannot control
examples: To a large extent the life you have depends on who your parents were; it’s just the luck of the biological draw.
